variant.question: The validity period of an eastbound organised track system in MNPS airspace is normally at 30°W, between:

options.text: Out of the validity period of organised flight track system
Within the organised daytime track system
Within the polar track system
Within the organised night-time track system

variant.question: For contingency in case of failure of INS/IRS computer systems during polar navigation, what should the pilot do?

Plot the flight plan on polar chart to measure required headings
Broadcast on air-to-air frequency 123.45 MHz and ask for help
Plot the current flight path on polar chart

variant.question: An aircraft flying at flight level 370 (FL 370) in MNPS Airspace is unable to continue flight in accordance with its air traffic control clearance (degradation of navigational performance requirements, mechanics troubles .... etc), but is able to maintain its assigned level (FL 370), and due to a total loss of communications capability, could not obtain a revised clearance from ATC. The aircraft should leave its assigned route or track by turning at least 30° (30 degrees) to the right or left whenever this is possible, and the subsequent action will be, turn to acquire and maintain in either direction a track laterally separated by 5 NM from its assigned route and:

options.text: Climb or descend 500 ft
Climb or descent 1 000 ft
Climb 500 ft or descend 1 000 ft
Climb or descent 1 000 ft or descend 500 ft

variant.question: If all long range navigation systems of an aircraft become unserviceable during a flight in MNPS airspace, and if no instructions are received from the air traffic control, you must consider:

options.text: climbing or descending 500 feet.
land at the nearest airport.
return to departure airport.
descend below the MNPS space.

variant.question: In the event of a contingency which required an en-route diversion to an alternate aerodrome across the direction of the prevailing 'NAT' traffic flow and if prior ATC clearance cannot be obtained, an aircraft not able to maintain its assigned flight level should

options.text: expedite its rate of descent while acquiring a 15 NM offset track.
immediately descend below FL280 and then acquire a 15 NM offset track.
immediately descend below FL280 and then acquire a 30 NM offset track.
minimise its rate of descent while acquiring a 30 NM offset track.

variant.question: If a pilot has received ATC clearance to deviate from track in the NAT HLA but maintain the assigned FL and then has to deviate further due to weather but cannot obtain a further clearance. The correct course of action for the deviation and return to track is:

options.text:
1. Before deviating beyond the cleared distance descend 300 ft if deviating towards the Pole.  
2. When returning to track, regain the assigned FL at 5 NM from the centre line before rejoining the assigned track.

1. Before deviating beyond the cleared distance climb 300 ft if deviating towards the Pole.  
2. When returning to track, regain the assigned FL at 5 NM from the centre line before rejoining the assigned track.

1. Before deviating beyond the cleared distance climb 500 ft if deviating towards the Pole.  
2. When returning to track, regain the assigned FL at 5 NM from the centre line before rejoining the assigned track.

1. Before deviating beyond the cleared distance descend 500 ft if deviating towards the Pole.  
2. When returning to track, regain the assigned FL at 5 NM from the centre line before rejoining the assigned track.

variant.question:
During a flight at FL 380 the aeroplane suffers a malfunction that leads to the failure of all autopilots and the flight crew are unable to restore them. 
What, if any, actions must the crew perform?

options.text: ATC must be advised that the aircraft is no longer in compliance with flight in RVSM airspace and the flight crew should expect to be instructed to descend to below FL 290.
The flight crew should divert to the nearest suitable airport where a safe landing can be made due to the excessive workload required by manual flight.
No action is required as the controllability of the aeroplane is unaffected, although pilot workload is increased significantly.
The flight crew must declare a MAYDAY as the aeroplane will suffer from reduced manoeuvrability and navigation ability due to the failure of all autopilots.

variant.question: When operating in the NAT HLA and having to avoid weather by 5 nm or more and  unable to obtain a revised clearance from ATC. Which of the following is the correct course of action?

options.text:
1. Deviate from track to avoid weather.
2. Maintain FL until 5 NM offset 
3. At 5 nm descend 300 ft, if deviating towards the Pole

1. Deviate from track to avoid weather.
2. Maintain FL until 5 NM offset 
3. At 5 nm descend 300 ft if deviating towards the Equator

1. Deviate from track to avoid weather.
2. Maintain FL until 5 NM offset 
3. At 5 nm descend 500 ft if deviating towards the Equator

1. Deviate from track to avoid weather.
2. Maintain FL until 5 NM offset 
3. At 5 nm descend 500 ft if deviating towards the Pole

variant.question: A repetitive flight plan (RPL) is filed for a scheduled flight Paris-Orly to Angouleme, Paris Orly as alternate. options.text: The RPL must be cancelled for that day and a specific flight plan has to be filed.
The pilot-in-command must advise ATC of his intention to divert to Limoges at least 15 minutes before the planned time of arrival.
It is not possible to plan another destination and the flight has to be simply cancelled that day (scheduled flight and not chartered).
The airline’s “Operations“ Department has to transmit a change in the RPL at the ATC office, at least half an hour before the planned time of departure.

Aircraft is converging towards its ideal course

variant.question: In case of a hi-jack, the squawk code is:

ICAO defines specific departure procedures for noise prevention. A hospital is located close to a runway on the extended centre line. To prevent aircraft noise, which flight technique describes the ICAO procedure to prevent aircraft noise at the hospital?

options.text: After lift-off immediately reduces thrust. Maintain V~2~+10 KIAS and at or above 3000 ft AGL reduce the climb rate to accelerate and retract flaps/slats.
Climb with maximum thrust and accelerate to retract flaps and slats as soon as possible. Continue the climb in a clean configuration. Maintain 250 KIAS below FL100.
Initially climb WITHOUT accelerating or reducing thrust. At 1500 ft AGL reduces thrust. At or above 3000 ft AGL reduces the climb rate to accelerate and retract flaps/ slats.
Initially climb with maximum thrust and WITHOUT accelerating. At or above 800 ft AGL reduce thrust and accelerate to retract the flaps/slats.

variant.question: Navigation tasks at high latitudes may be complicated due to:

options.text: The convergence of the meridians.
The divergence of the meridians.
The conversion of grid navigation data into compass navigation data.
The INS rigidity in space.

variant.question: Magnetic compasses become unreliable in polar regions because of the...

options.text: reduced horizontal field strength.
fluctuating field strength.
reduced vertical field strength.
increased horizontal and vertical field strengths.

variant.question: You are flying a route which takes you close to the Magnetic North Pole and within the Canadian Northern Domestic Airspace. Which of the following considerations should be made?

options.text: The magnetic compass may be unreliable or unusable; basic inertial navigation requires NO special procedures.
The Earth's vertical field strength is reduced and the ability of the compass to accurately sense Magnetic North is reduced.
To check their position only NDBs should be used to obtain bearings and these should then be converted to true bearings using the magnetic variation at the station.
Their DR position should be cross-checked with a bearing from a VOR, which should then be converted to true using the magnetic variation at the aircraft.

variant.question: There is a hijacker who just got in the flight crew compartment and they destroyed all the radio instruments. What should you do?

options.text: Try to contact ATC via CPDLC.
Ask the cabin crew to restrain the hijacker.
Do nothing for the safety of passengers.
You should advise via ADS-B.
